abstract: Background Immunization supply chains in low resource settings do not always reach children with necessary vaccines. Digital information systems can enable real time visibility of inventory and improve vaccine availability. In 2014, a digital, mobile/web-based information system was implemented in two districts of Uttar Pradesh, India. This retrospective investigates improvements and stabilization of supply chain performance following introduction of the digital information system. Methods All data were collected via the digital information system between March 2014 and September 2015. Data included metadata and transaction logs providing information about users, facilities, and vaccines. Metrics evaluated include adoption (system access, timeliness and completeness), data quality (error rates), and performance (stock availability on immunization session days, replenishment response duration, rate of zero stock events). Stability was defined as the phase in which quality and performance metrics achieved equilibrium rates with minimal volatility. The analysis compared performance across different facilities and vaccines. Results Adoption appeared sufficiently high from the onset to commence stability measures of data quality and supply chain performance. Data quality stabilized from month 3 onwards, and supply chain performance stabilized from month 13 onwards. For data quality, error rates reduced by two thirds post stabilization. Although vaccine availability remained high throughout the pilot, the three lowest-performing facilities improved from 91.05% pre-stability to 98.70% post-stability (p < 0.01; t-test). Average replenishment duration (as a corrective response to stock-out events) decreased 52.3% from 4.93 days to 2.35 days (p < 0.01; t-test). Diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis vaccine was significantly less likely to be stocked out than any other material. Conclusion The results suggest that given sufficient adoption, stability is sequentially achieved, beginning with data quality, and then performance. Identifying when a pilot stabilizes can enable more predictable, reliable cost estimates, and outcome forecasts in the scale-up phase.

author_highlights.sentence: Mobile/web vaccine supply chain information system serving 7.45 million population.
Data quality stabilized at month 3, followed by vaccine availability at month 13.
Data quality and vaccine availability improvements persisted post-stabilization.
Performance differences across antigens indicate importance of granular data.

body_text.sentence: The program ran from March 2014 to September 2015, and included three interventions:
body_text.title: Context of the Uttar Pradesh pilot

body_text.sentence: Real time inventory visibility via digital LMIS (product): Mobile/web software working seamlessly across devices (Java handsets, smartphones, tablets, and desktop computers), operating systems (Windows, Android, J2ME), browsers (Chrome, Safari, Internet Explorer), transmission channels (WiFi, GPRS, SMS), and connectivity scenarios (synchronous, asynchronous, and offline caching/synching).
body_text.title: Context of the Uttar Pradesh pilot

body_text.sentence: Standardization of data collection (process): Simple paper recording tools to tabulate stock utilization for a given session, and generate outputs for digital data capture.
body_text.title: Context of the Uttar Pradesh pilot

body_text.sentence: The data suggest a sequential pattern of sufficient adoption (month 1), followed by stable data quality (month 3), followed by stable supply chain performance (month 13).

body_text.title: iSCM context

body_text.sentence: Prior to the pilot, vaccine replenishment in Uttar Pradesh was ad hoc, as was generally the case throughout India [15].
body_text.title: Context of the Uttar Pradesh pilot

body_text.sentence: Each district receives vaccines from state level stores, and allocates these to cold chain equipped facilities (CCPs) throughout the district (23 in Bareilly, 16 in Shahjahanpur).
body_text.title: Context of the Uttar Pradesh pilot

body_text.sentence: Replenishment plans and standard operating procedures (SOP’s) existed, but were rarely enforced, resulting in disjointed movement of vaccines from state to district to health facility [15].
body_text.title: Context of the Uttar Pradesh pilot

body_text.sentence: The majority of its population (77.7%) resides in rural areas [14].
body_text.title: Context of the Uttar Pradesh pilot

body_text.sentence: Unfortunately, LMIS’s today suffer from incomplete and delayed data entry, poor data quality, and lack of use [2,3].
body_text.title: iSCM context

body_text.sentence: Strengthened human capacity (people): Introduction of accountable district level staff – Vaccine Logistics & Cold Chain Managers (VCCM’s) – overseeing the cold chain and managing stock across facilities to prevent over and under stocking.
body_text.title: Context of the Uttar Pradesh pilot

body_text.sentence: After the implementation of the pilot, the number of zero-stock events declined dramatically, suggesting sufficient proactive behavior by users to prevent stockouts.
body_text.title: Performance

body_text.sentence: For the zero-stock events that did occur, the proportion that resulted in stockouts remained constant at a mean of 75.73% (ơ = 0.05) despite shorter replenishment response times (see supplementary materials for more information).
body_text.title: Performance

body_text.sentence: Average rates across all 19 months were moderate with values at 82.47% (ơ = 5.67) for access, 77.64% (ơ = 6.79) for completeness and 84.34% (ơ = 6.83) for timeliness.
body_text.title: Adoption

body_text.sentence: The digital LMIS must accommodate a complex system composed of national, state, district, and sub district layers, and manage a growing, increasingly diverse set of users.
body_text.title: Conclusion

body_text.sentence: Surges in error levels in Q2 2015 correspond with “Mission Indradhanush”,2 weeklong events providing high volumes of routine immunizations, daily, throughout low performing districts, including Bareilly and Shahjahanpur.
body_text.title: Data quality

body_text.sentence: ITSU designated incumbent, CPP level health workers overseeing vaccine supply as Cold Chain Handlers (CCH’s), and provided them one day of training.
body_text.title: Context of the Uttar Pradesh pilot

body_text.sentence: Implementing the mobile/web LMIS, alongside people and process interventions, resulted in strong user adoption of the digital information system, low error rates, and enhanced availability of vaccines within the Indian supply chain system.
body_text.title: Conclusion

body_text.sentence: All data were collected via digital LMIS users, as part of their routine operations (see Appendix II), and hosted on a secure password-protected server.
